update.description:
Slightly modified semantics of set_passed_properties.

* non-keyword arguments can now be saved as well as keyword arguments.
* If an instance attribute exists with the same name as an argument after
   `__init__` runs, its value will be saved instead.

The non-keyword arguments simply fixes a deficiency, presently, to get auto-saving of properties you have to pass in the properties as keyword arguments - if you pass them in as positional args, things break pretty confusingly. There is a workaround in the NI devices at the moment in which clock_terminal is saved as a property at the end of `generate_code` instead of using `set_passed_properties` to get around this.

Instance attributes taking precedence over passed args allows you to be smarter with default arguments. For example it's bad form to have mutable default arguments, and so where one would be used, common idiom is to instead set the default argument to `None` and within the method do something like:
```python
self. foo = foo if foo is not None else {}
```
Similarly in our NI_DAQmx classes, the default for `MAX_name`, if not specified, is to use the labscript device name. The logic for this is in `NIBoard.__init__`:
```python
self.MAX_name = name if MAX_name is None else MAX_name
```
 Although BLACS_connection is used to talk to the device and so it doesn't matter, the value of `MAX_name` saved as a device_property, doesn't respect this processing that may have been done, and so might simply be wrong.
update.title: Changes to set_passed_properties

content.raw:
Thanks for testing!

I'm not sure why this could have triggered a recompilation-needed notification. I don't think it is watching labscript.py for changes. I've seen false positives for recompilation in other contexts, but I'm not sure what is causing them.
content.html:
Thanks for testing!

I'm not sure why this could have triggered a recompilation-needed notification. I don't think it is watching labscript.py for changes. I've seen false positives for recompilation in other contexts, but I'm not sure what is causing them.

content.raw:
In our lab everything seems to work fine with this. I even found a typo in some other piece of code due to this PR :smiley:   
When introducing these changes, I had to recompile the connection table although it was not changed. Is this because “labscript.py” was changed?
content.html:
In our lab everything seems to work fine with this. I even found a typo in some other piece of code due to this PR
When introducing these changes, I had to recompile the connection table although it was not changed. Is this because “labscript.py” was changed?

content.raw:
Further change: set_passed_properties allows you to save instance attributes even if they are not call arguments. As before if an instance attribute has the same name as an argument, the value of the instance attribute will be saved.

This is useful because I want to save 'clock_limit' as a connection table property for the generic DAQmx device, but it is computed during `__init__` as the minimum of the maximum digital and analog buffered rates for the device (which may be different).
content.html:
Further change: set_passed_properties allows you to save instance attributes even if they are not call arguments. As before if an instance attribute has the same name as an argument, the value of the instance attribute will be saved.

This is useful because I want to save 'clock_limit' as a connection table property for the generic DAQmx device, but it is computed during __init__ as the minimum of the maximum digital and analog buffered rates for the device (which may be different).

update.description:
Slightly modified semantics of set_passed_properties.

* non-keyword arguments can now be saved as well as keyword arguments.
* If an instance attribute exists with the same name as an argument after
   `__init__` runs, its value will be saved instead.

The non-keyword arguments simply fixes a deficiency, presently, to get auto-saving of properties you have to pass in the properties as keyword arguments - if you pass them in as positional args, things break pretty confusingly. There is a workaround in the NI devices at the moment in which clock_terminal is saved as a property at the end of `generate_code` instead of using `set_passed_properties` to get around this.

Instance attributes taking precedence over passed args allows you to be smarter with default arguments. For example it's bad form to have mutable default arguments, and so where one would be used, common idiom is to instead set the default argument to `None` and within the method do something like:
```python

```
Similarly in our NI_DAQmx classes, the default for `MAX_name`, if not specified, is to use the labscript device name. The logic for this is in `NIBoard.__init__`:
```python
self.MAX_name = name if MAX_name is None else MAX_name
```
 Although BLACS_connection is used to talk to the device and so it doesn't matter, the value of `MAX_name` saved as a device_property, doesn't respect this processing that may have been done, and so might simply be wrong.

update.description:
Slightly modified semantics of set_passed_properties.

    * non-keyword arguments can now be saved as well as keyword arguments.
    * If an instance attribute exists with the same name as an argument after
      `__init__` runs, its value will be saved instead.

* Version bump

The non-keyword arguments simply fixes a deficiency, presently, to get auto-saving of properties you have to pass in the properties as keyword arguments - if you pass them in as positional args, things break pretty confusingly. There is a workaround in the NI devices at the moment in which clock_terminal is saved as a property at the end of `generate_code` instead of using `set_passed_properties` to get around this.

Instance attributes taking precedence over passed args allows you to be smarter with default arguments. For example it's bad form to have mutable default arguments, and so where one would be used, common idiom is to instead set the default argument to `None` and within the method do something like:
```python

```
Similarly in our NI_DAQmx classes, the default for `MAX_name`, if not specified, is to use the labscript device name. The logic for this is in `NIBoard.__init__`:
```python

```
 Although BLACS_connection is used to talk to the device and so it doesn't matter, the value of `MAX_name` saved as a device_property, doesn't respect this processing that may have been done, and so might simply be wrong.
